Review:
Most of us have been to the kind of crowded house parties where you hang back and people-watch in relative anonymity. If you were to document it all from afar, who might you see? What might you overhear? On his new album The Party, Andy Shauf puts himself in that exact position, as he crafts a series of connected vignettes that offer up tiny observations from a single night. Considering the songsâ€™ rotating first-person viewpoints, Shauf also employs these archetypes as stand-ins to consider his personal faults â€” and even portray the loneliness and claustrophobia that can come with living in a small town. In â€œThe Worst In You,â€ Shauf embodies someone who wrongly assumes that his significant other is cheating when he canâ€™t find her at the party. â€œWhy do I always find the worst in you?â€ he wonders. â€œDo you always find the worst in me?â€

Instead of winning her over, he tipsily oversteps and self-servingly throws his friend under the bus. â€œYou know Iâ€™ve never really met someone like you,â€ he sings clumsily, unwittingly pushing her back into the arms of his friend. In the follow-up, â€œBegin Again,â€ Shauf is stuck as the same friend brags about seeing someone else on the side. â€œI donâ€™t give a damn about you fooling around behind Sherryâ€™s back / Itâ€™s just the one that you found is one that I need.â€ As he fumes, he imagines the power to end the conversation in post-apocalyptic fashion â€” â€œOh, from the sky, a brilliant light will dissolve us allâ€ â€” just as his voice expands into shimmering cosmic echoes.

Shauf melds chipper British pop and breezy folk for a sound built from lush pianos, mellow acoustic guitars and jazzy rhythms. The result recalls classic pop songwriters in the vein of Harry Nilsson or Randy Newman, coupled with the plainspoken timbre of a Paul Simon, albeit with a laconic Canadian drawl. Shauf also possesses a keen, emotive ear for complex arrangements and lavish orchestrations. First working in Germany, and later at a studio in the old CBC building in Regina, Shauf performs every instrument on the album except the strings, which were played by Colin Nealis.
